awd_titl_txt: FIRSTS (Foundation for Increasing and Retaining STEM Students) Program: A bridge program to study the sociological development of science identities
awd_abstract_narration:
FIRSTS (Foundation for Increasing and Retaining STEM Students) is an extended summer bridge program for incoming students that continues through their first semester at college.  The overall goals of this program are to help students from underserved populations transition to the rigors of the STEM curriculum and gather both qualitative and quantitative data on the reasons financially needy students elect to leave STEM disciplines.  Rather than simply filling content gaps, FIRSTS will use the remediation of study skills in a interdisciplinary summer course, extensive mentoring, and the development of a science identity to improve success in STEM disciplines.  In addition to student-focused strategies, the program also will incorporate faculty development in the improvement of teaching methods and mentoring through participation, training, interdisciplinary interactions, and discussions.  

FIRSTS will leverage the existing college-funded programming that is focused on predominantly underrepresented minority students from regions of historic poverty and will carefully pilot an expansion to include School of Science students with similar profiles.  This program will deploy best practices for at-risk students, while focusing the research on understudied questions related to the impact of socioeconomic status, intersecting science and other identities.  As such, FIRSTS will represent the unique data-driven collaboration between the School of Science and the School of Humanities and Social Sciences on pedagogy and research. If successful, the data from this project will allow other departments, colleges, and universities to incorporate a developmental philosophy in their existing STEM retention strategies.

por.por_cntn:
The FIRSTS (Foundation for Increasing and Retaining STEM Students) Program: A bridge program to study the sociological development of science identities had four specific goals: 

  1. Help students transition to The College of New Jersey (TCNJ, a PUI)

  2. Lower the rate of students obtaining a grade of D, F, or W in introductory courses

  3. Improve and sustain the campus climate through faculty training

  4. Conduct a robust sociological research project on student success and bridge programs.  

In particular, the fourth goal seizes a collaboration opportunity between The College of New Jersey School of Science and the Department of Sociology to conduct a substantial research project to understand why and how these best practices work including: 

  • Why do students leave STEM majors?

  • How do science identities form in students?

  • How do students gain cultural capital to utilize resources?

  • How do social networks between faculty and students form and affect persistence? 

Across the first three summers, we served 114 students, or about 5% of those matriculating into majors in the Schools of Science; Engineering; and Nursing, Health, and Exercise Science. Eighty percent of Summer Scholars were from groups underrepresented in the sciences.  The early longitudinal results from our program at The College of New Jersey are quite promising.  For example, across the first three cohorts, 70% of summer scholars remained in STEM by the end of fall semester 2019; 40% have GPAs above the college mean (>3.2). The rest have left the college (14%) or switched out of STEM (14%).  The students that left STEM (or the college) have been a rich resource of information on potential future interventions to help struggling students.  Among Summer Scholars, we found much higher rates of survivorship (staying in STEM but with GPAs below the mean) by the end of the first year compared to all other students (58% vs. 42%, chi squared = 0.048). Importantly, by the end of the second year, the Summer Scholars students had similar survivor proportions (Summer Scholars Program: 31.0%, non-Summer Scholars Program: 32.2%).  We have a robust database of Interview data collected at the end of the Summer Scholars Program and spring semesters that revealed some interesting patterns. Whereas nearly all of the first two cohorts of Summer Scholars were top 10 in their high schools (68/72), few reported needing to study to succeed in their high school classes.  In fact comments such as the following were common:  “I learned how to study here in the summer program cause like I said in high school I didn’t really need to study at all…like at all” (Black, Male, Mathematics major). This led many of our students to experience “grade shock” for the first time during the summer. However, the time it took for students to make the connection between realizing “like, I really gotta study if I wanna pass the class” (White, Female, Physics major) and changing studying behavior to “if I didn’t do well on an exam I might try something different” (Asian, Female, Biology major) correlated with their status as survivors or thrivers.  Based on the data we have collected, a significant portion of the program is devoted to the transition from high school to college study skills and the recovery from traumatic “grade shock” experience.

This project provides a general structure for further gains across TCNJ and similar institutions by refining our understanding of 1) how contexts like TCNJ, as a public PUI, can minimize structural barriers and maximize structural supports to college success and STEM persistence and 2) how programs can support students in developing resilience strategies. Specifically, we want to promote diversity and inclusion by studying how students take up and deploy resources (such as mentoring and instruction) to move forward in college, make short and long term decisions about science engagement, and integrate social identities (such as racial, ethnic, sexuality, and class identities) with science identities. Ultimately, we believe that this will lead to a diverse population within multiple professions, including medicine, engineering, and nursing.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/17/2022
Modified by: Sudhir B Nayak
